logger module¶

class logger.CustomFormatter(fmt=None, datefmt=None, style='%')¶

Bases: logging.Formatter

Logging Formatter to add colors and count warning / errors

FORMATS = {10: '\x1b[38;21m[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s (%(filename)s:%(lineno)d)\x1b[0m', 20: '\x1b[32;21m[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s\x1b[0m', 30: '\x1b[33;21m[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s (%(filename)s:%(lineno)d)\x1b[0m', 40: '\x1b[31;21m[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s (%(filename)s:%(lineno)d)\x1b[0m', 50: '\x1b[31;1m[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s (%(filename)s:%(lineno)d)\x1b[0m'}¶
bold_red = '\x1b[31;1m'¶
format(record)¶

Format the specified record as text.

The record’s attribute dictionary is used as the operand to a string formatting operation which yields the returned string. Before formatting the dictionary, a couple of preparatory steps are carried out. The message attribute of the record is computed using LogRecord.getMessage(). If the formatting string uses the time (as determined by a call to usesTime(), formatTime() is called to format the event time. If there is exception information, it is formatted using formatException() and appended to the message.

format_all = '[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s (%(filename)s:%(lineno)d)'¶
format_info = '[%(asctime)s] [%(levelname)s]...%(message)s'¶
green = '\x1b[32;21m'¶
grey = '\x1b[38;21m'¶
red = '\x1b[31;21m'¶
reset = '\x1b[0m'¶
yellow = '\x1b[33;21m'¶
